questions.text: A 30 year old construction manager presented with persistent abdominal pain, nausea, fatigue, and episodes of vomiting and diarrhoea over several months. His symptoms progressively worsened, and he developed skin changes, including darkening and hyperkeratosis on his palms and soles. Blood tests confirmed heavy metal poisoning. Which of the following is the preferred test and treatment for this condition?
questions.correct_answer: C. Atomic absorption spectroscopy and BAL
questions.explanation:
Tests

  • The following tests estimate the concentration of arsenic in hair, bone, and nails:
  • Neutron activation analysis (NAA) (Option A)
  • Atomic absorption spectroscopy (AAS) (Option C)
 
  • The following tests are obsolete now:
    • Marsh test (Option B)
    • Reinsch test
    • Gutzeit test (Option D)

Urine levels

>50 microns in 24 hours indicates arsenic poisoning (Best)

Blood level

Serum arsenic > 0.9 µg/dl

Hair level

Best sample: Pubic hair (used for long-term exposure detection).

Radiography

Abdominal X-ray: May show arsenic presence in the gastrointestinal tract in cases of acute poisoning.

Others

  • CBC, serum electrolytes, liver and renal function tests.
  • ECG and continuous cardiac monitoring in symptomatic patients.
  • Chest X-ray: For severe poisoning or pulmonary involvement.
  • Monitoring and medical surveillance are required for employees exposed to arsenic.

Supportive treatment

Gastric lavage, airway, breathing, and circulation management (intravenous fluids, cardiac monitoring, etc.).

Medical treatment

Freshly prepared hydrated ferric oxide (chemical antidote)

Chelating agents
  • BAL (Dimercaprol) (Option C)
  • DMSA (Dimercapto succinic acid) or DMPS (Dimercapto propane sulfonic acid)
  • Penicillamine

Other measures
  • Purgatives like Castor oil or Magnesium sulfate (remove unabsorbed poison from the intestine).
  • Glucose-saline with sodium bicarbonate.
  • Hemodialysis or exchange transfusion.

questions.text: A 39 year old man presents to the emergency department after consuming homemade alcohol, showing headache, dizziness, nausea, vomiting, blurred vision, confusion, and metabolic acidosis. Methanol poisoning is suspected, and treatment with fomepizole is initiated. Which mechanism explains how fomepizole mitigates methanol toxicity?

options.label: A
options.text: It is a competitive inhibitor to Methanol

options.label: B
options.text: Increases the excretion of Formic acid

questions.explanation:
Methanol Poisoning

Other names for methanol

Wood Alcohol/ Illicit Alcohol

Absorption and Metabolism
  • Absorbed through the stomach, intestine, also lungs and skin
  • Alcohol dehydrogenase helps in forming
    • Formaldehyde from Methanol
    • Formic acid from Formaldehyde

Action
  • It is a CNS depressant and causes high serum osmolality
  • Formic acid is responsible for Metabolic acidosis and Retinal Toxicity

Fatal Dose and Fatal Period

60- 200 ml and 24 - 36 hours

Symptoms
  • Initially similar to ethanol poisoning
  • Severe Abdominal cramps (early symptom)
  • Neck Stiffness
  • Vertigo
  • Dilated and fixed pupils
  • Muscle Weakness
  • Snowfield Vision and Optic neuritis
  • Cardiac and CNS depression
  • Coma
  • Severe Metabolic Acidosis (Common cause of death)

Treatment
  • Gastric Lavage with 5% bicarbonate solution
  • Activated Charcoal
  • Antidote:
    • Ethanol - Competitive inhibitor to Methanol
    • Fomepizole - Competitive inhibitor of alcohol dehydrogenase
  • Folinic or Folic acid: Increases excretion of Formic acid
  • Sodium Bicarbonate: To manage acidosis
  • Hemodialysis: Treatment of choice in severe poisoning

Postmortem Findings
  • Marked Cyanosis
  • Absent postmortem clotting of blood
  • Hemorrhagic necrosis of putamen

Hooch Tragedy is mass poisonings and deaths in India from consuming toxic illicit alcohol in the 2000s.

questions.text: A 35 year old male presents with confusion, disorientation, nystagmus and impaired vision with a history of chronic alcoholism. On examination, he had ataxia and ophthalmoplegia. What is the likely condition that is causing these symptoms?
questions.explanation:
Chronic Alcoholism Manifestations

Wernicke's Encephalopathy
  • Caused by Thiamine Deficiency
  • Symptoms
    • Global confusion, ataxia and Apathy (early symptoms)
    • Polyneuropathy
    • Ophthalmoplegia
    • Disorientation, recent memory loss and loss of attention span
  • Rx - IV Thiamine followed by oral thiamine.

Korsakoff Psychosis (Option C)
  • Caused by untreated Wernicke's Encephalopathy
  • Symptoms
    • Confabulation
    • Retrograde and Anterograde Amnesia
    • Difficulty in learning new things
    • Severe Disorientation.
  • Rx - IV Thiamine followed by oral thiamine

MarChiafava's Syndrome (Option B)
  • Caused by degeneration of Corpus callosum
  • Symptoms
    • Intellectual Disorientation
    • Epilepsy,
    • Ataxia
    • Dysarthria
    • Hallucinations
    • Spastic paralysis of the limb
    • Dementia
  • Rx: Thiamine supplementation (especially in alcohol-related cases), antiepileptic drugs for seizures, and supportive therapies like physical and speech therapy for motor and speech deficits. Psychiatric care may be needed for hallucinations and cognitive impairment.

Alcohol Paranoia

Paranoid delusions are present with no hallucinations

Mallory Weiss Syndrome (Option A)

It involves tears in the esophageal mucosa caused by severe vomiting or retching, which can lead to gastrointestinal bleeding and mediastinitis.

questions.text: A 45 year old man with a history of chronic alcohol use presents to the emergency department after abrupt cessation of drinking for three days. He exhibits agitation and tremors. On examination, he has diaphoresis. Which of the following symptoms may also occur in alcohol withdrawal 72 hours after cessation?
questions.explanation:
Alcohol Withdrawal Symptoms

Symptom

Time since the last drink

Explanation

Tremors

6 - 8 hours
  • First symptoms to occur
  • Tremors affecting hands, legs and trunk

Hallucination

< 48 hours
  • Visual and Auditory Hallucinations
  • Rx: Chlorpromazine

Seizures

> 1 day
  • Tonic-Clonic seizures
  • Rum - fits
  • Sometimes, it can happen when the person is drinking also

Delirium Tremens

2 - 4 days
  • It can happen due to sudden excessive consumption, stoppage, sudden injury, or acute infection in chronic alcoholics.
  • It is a severe condition
  • Disorientation to time, place, and person
  • Insomnia (Option C) Restlessness, agitation, confusion, and temporary memory loss
  • Coarse tremors (face, hand, tongue)
  • Tachycardia, Tachypnea, Hypertension (Options A and B) (Autonomic Hyperactivity)
  • Hallucinations are visual, auditory, and tactile.
  • Rarely causes death due to shock, cardiac failure, or cerebral oedema
  • IPC 84 - Crime is not punishable under this condition
  • Rx: Diazepam (Agitation)
    • Chlordiazepoxide (Withdrawal)
    • Chlorpromazine (Sedation)
    • Symptomatic management.

questions.text: A 32-year-old male weighing 100 kg was arrested for disorderly conduct at a market. Upon questioning, he confesses to consuming 100 grams of alcohol. Using the Widmark formula, calculate his Blood Alcohol Concentration (BAC). (The Widmark constant for men is 0.68)
questions.explanation:
Widmark Formula is A = PCR
  • A - Weight of alcohol
  • P - Body weight
  • C - Blood Alcohol Concentration
  • R - is a constant (Fat- water ratio), Men - 0.68, Women - 0.55

Kozelka Test

  

Qualitative tests (Macro method)

Hena Test

Cavett Test

Qualitative test (Micro method)

Gas Chromatography

Used in Medicolegal cases

Qualitative + Quantitative test.

Breathalyzer Test
  • It follows Henry’s law and uses infrared rays to detect alcohol vapour in exhaled breath, converting this measurement into an estimated blood alcohol concentration.
  • The current legal level of alcohol for driving is 30 mg%. (Motor Vehicle Act)

Terms used based on BAC

< 10 mg%

Sober

10 - 80 mg%

Drinking

80 - 150 mg%

Under influence

150 - 300 mg%

Intoxicated

> 300 mg%

Coma

questions.text: A 28 year old male was brought to the ED after multiple episodes of vomiting, confusion, and irritability following alcohol consumption at a party. He had a flushed face, sensory impairment, and a heart rate of 105. He was suspected to be in the 2nd phase of intoxication. What is the likely blood alcohol concentration (BAC)?
questions.explanation:
Stages of intoxication

Stages

BAC in mg%

Symptoms

Excitement

30 - 150
  • There is slight impairment in the cognitive, sensory and motor functions at 30 mg%
  • Impaired reaction time at 50 mg%
  • Alcohol gaze nystagmus, low pain sensitivity, and poor concentration at 80 - 100mg%
  • Nausea and slight movement incoordination is seen from 100 - 150 mg%

Incoordination

150 - 250
  • Nausea and Vomiting
  • Sensory, Fine, and Skilled motor impairment
  • Elevated heart rate
  • Flushed face

Coma

> 300
  • Markedly affected speech (Thick and slurred speech), as well as sensory and motor functions.
  • Extreme dizziness and a sense of fall are present.
  • Positive McEwan’s sign: The patient's pupils are contracted, which dilate on a stimulus like a pinch or a slap and later return to the contracted phase.
  • Usually recovers in 8 to 10 hours with a hangover.

Factors increasing Absorption

Factors decreasing Absorption
  • Mixing of drinks
  • Drinking with Carbonated drinks (due to the increased surface area carrying alcohol)
  • Warm drink
  • Gastrectomy patients
  • Drinking on an Empty stomach
  • Chronic alcoholism
  • Drinking after a mixed meal
  • Cool Drink
  • Achlorhydria
  • Chronic gastritis
  • In Pyloric spasm
  • With Drugs reducing gastric motility (Atropine and Benzene)

Sample

Relative Concentration of alcohol in mg% at equilibrium

Whole Blood

1.00

Plasma

1.12 - 1.2

Brain and Liver

0.85

Urine

1.3

Vitreous

1.2

Alveolar air

0.0021

CSF

1.1

questions.text: A 30 year old male is brought to the emergency department by friends after acting erratically in public, hallucinating, and showing aggressive behaviour. He is agitated and confused and has dilated pupils and a rapid heart rate. While his vital signs are stable, he becomes more aggressive when approached. Which substance might be abused in this case?
questions.explanation:
Source

Synthesised from piperazine, cyclohexanone, and potassium cyanide

Street names

Angel dust.

Mode of intake

Smoking; Insufflation; Ingestion; Parenteral (rare)

Combination

  • Mixed with parsley, mint, oregano, or marijuana.
  • Tragic magico: Crack (cocaine) is dipped in PCP and smoked
  • Love boat: Cannabis is dipped in PCP and smoked.

Mechanism

Blocking NMDA receptor-mediated neurotransmission and presynaptic monoamine reuptake, increasing dopamine and noradrenaline synaptic levels.

Clinical features

  • Acute psychosis and agitation (violent behaviour).
  • PCP: Symptoms like confusion, disorientation, amnesia, catatonia, dystonic movements, mydriasis, tachycardia, hallucinations (auditory and visual), blank stare, nystagmus, blurred vision, etc.
  • Cannabis: Symptoms like euphoria, disorientation, hallucinations (visual and auditory), sedation, dysphoria, tachycardia, palpitations, hypotension, appetite stimulation, etc.

Management
  • Supportive Care and Monitoring
  • Sedation with Benzodiazepines: Administer benzodiazepines (e.g., lorazepam or diazepam) to control agitation, anxiety, and seizures. Avoid antipsychotics as they may worsen agitation.
  • Hydration and Renal Support: Provide intravenous fluids to maintain hydration and support renal function, especially in cases of myoglobinuria or acute renal failure.

questions.text: A 25 year old male presents to the emergency department exhibiting severe agitation, hallucinations, and a heightened sense of paranoia after attending a rave. He reports feelings of overwhelming anxiety and visual distortions, claiming he sees colours and shapes that aren't there. Based on his symptoms, which substance is most likely responsible for his bad trip?
questions.explanation:
Lysergic acid diethylamide

Source

Claviceps purpurea or rye fungus (ergot alkaloid).

Sold as

  • Acid blotter
  • Paper stamp
  • Tiny tablets (microdots)
  • Gelatin squares (window panes)
  • Liquid or powder

Mode

Oral intake; Smoke (rare); Parenteral (rare)

Mechanism

5HT-1 receptor agonist (increases serotonin level)

Fatal dose

14 mg

Clinical manifestations
  • Good trip: Psychotropic effect consisting of euphoria including visual hallucinations, illusions, sensations of synesthesia (seeing smell or hearing colours)
  • Bad trip: Psychotropic effect consisting of an acute panic reaction as paranoid delusion, violent behaviour, anxiety, automatism, or depersonalisation.
  • Symptoms like sweating, dry mouth, mydriasis, hypertension, tachycardia, mood change, etc.
  • Bizarre perceptual changes: Faces and body parts appear distorted, objects undulate, sounds may be amplified and distorted, and colours seem brighter with halos around them.
  • Flashback phenomenon: The individual experiences a recurrence of the emotional and psychological aspects from the previous LSD trip.

Management

  • Anti-anxiety drugs (Low dose)
  • Benzodiazepines (Diazepam)
  • Prolonged talking involves verbal reassurance to keep the person grounded and reduce paranoia.
  • Psychotherapy

questions.text: A 35 year old man who works in a jewelry factory is brought to the emergency department drowsy, with sudden irritability, confusion, and vomiting over 24 hours. Examination shows a bluish line on his gums and pallor, and blood tests confirm acute heavy metal poisoning with cerebral oedema on the CT scan. Along with maintenance ofairway, breathing, and circulation, what is the immediate management?
questions.explanation:
Management of Lead Poisoning

Severe acute poisoning with encephalopathy

  • BAL or Dimercaprol (administered immediately) (Option D)
  • CaNa2EDTA (calcium disodium edetate) (contraindicated in renal failure)
  • For Cerebral edema:
    • Mannitol
    • Furosemide
    • Corticosteroids (Dexamethasone)
  • Continue until the patient is asymptomatic, then start oral chelation (D-penicillamine or DMSA).

Severe acute poisoning without encephalopathy

(Blood Lead level >70 mcg/100 ml)

  • BAL
  • EDTA
  • When BL <40 mcg/100 ml
    • Discontinue BAL
    • Continue EDTA
    • Change to oral chelation (D-penicillamine or DMSA).

Moderate poisoning

(Blood Lead level: 45-70 mcg/100 ml)
  • EDTA
  • When BL <40 mcg/100ml: Oral chelation (D-penicillamine or DMSA)

Mild poisoning

(Blood Lead level: 20-35 mcg/100 ml)
  • D-penicillamine (Option C) or
  • DMSA (dimercaptosuccinic acid) (Option B)

Supportive measures
  • Thiamine
  • Calcium gluconate (Option A)
  • Magnesium sulphate
  • DMSA (succimer)

questions.text: A 5-year-old child presents with developmental delay, irritability, and abdominal pain. Laboratory investigations for lead poisoning are ordered. Which of the following is the definitive indicator of lead poisoning?

options.label: B
options.text: Increased levels of urinary coproporphyrin (>150 mcg/litre)

questions.correct_answer: C. Blood lead level >40 micrograms/100 ml
questions.explanation:
Blood analysis

CBC and Peripheral Blood Smear
  • Microcytic-hypochromic anemia
  • Anisocytosis
  • Poikilocytosis and Polycythemia
  • Basophilic stippling (Option B) and Cabot rings in RBCs

Blood lead levels (BL)
  • >5 microgram/ 100 ml (lead exposure)
  • >40 micrograms (appearance of signs and symptoms)

ZnP (Zinc Protoporphyrin) levels

35-50 microgram/ 100 ml.

FEP (Free Erythrocyte Protoporphyrin)

Elevated

Urine analysis

ALA (Amino Levulinic Acid) levels

>5 micrograms/L

Urinary coproporphyrin level

>150 mcg /litre

Urine lead level

0.25 milligram/ litre.

Calcium disodium EDTA mobilisation test

This test is primarily conducted in children to determine whether they will respond to chelation therapy with a significant lead diuresis.

questions.text: A 5-year-old girl is brought to the paediatrician due to irritability, decreased appetite, abdominal pain, and difficulty concentrating. She exhibits signs of anaemia and pallor, as depicted in the image below. Blood tests confirm heavy metal poisoning. Which clinical manifestations are not typically associated with this condition?
questions.explanation:
Chronic lead poisoning (also known as Plumbism or Saturnism)

Clinical manifestations

Description

Facial pallor


 

It is caused by vasospasm and specifically occurs circumorally, which is the earliest and most specific feature.

 

Anemia
  • Type: Microcytic-hypochromic.
  • Enzymes inhibited:
    • Ferrochelatase
    • ALA-dehydratase
    • Coproporphyrinogen oxidase
 
  • Blood picture:
    • Cabot rings in RBCs
    • Microcytic-hypochromic
    • Sideroblasts (nucleated red cells)
    • Anisocytosis
    • Poikilocytosis
    • Polycythemia

Basophilic stippling or Punctate basophilia (Option B)
  • Multiple blue-coloured pinhead dots in RBCs due to the toxic action of lead on porphyrin metabolism (inhibition of enzyme 5- Pyrimidine nucleotidase) (PNN).
  • Accumulation of ribosomes in RBC

Lead line or Burtonian lines (Option A)

The stippled blue line observed on the gums, resulting from a subepithelial deposit of granules that develops within one week, is seen in 50-70% of cases and is more common in individuals with carious teeth (bacteria form lead sulfide).

Lead osteopathy/Lead line (Bone-line) (Option D)

In children, calcium deposition occurs at the growth plates of bones (specifically the lower end of the femur and the upper end of the tibia), which appears as a radiopaque band and occurs over 4 weeks due to the inhibition of osteoclastic activity.

Colic and constipation

(Painter's Colic or Devonshire colic)

Late presentation occurs in 85% of cases, typically at night, and is characterised by spasmodic pain relieved by pressure.

Lead palsy

Predominantly motor features include:

  • Dry belly ache
  • Wrist drop (Radial nerve)

  • Foot drop (Common peroneal nerve)

Encephalopathy

This condition is seen in nearly all cases, is associated with tetraethyl lead exposure, primarily affects children, results in permanent brain damage in 85% of cases, and accounts for 25% of fatalities.

Reproductive system
  • Amenorrhea
  • Dysmenorrhea
  • Abortion
  • Sterility derangements (both sexes)

Cardiovascular system and Kidneys
  • Hypertension (vascular constriction)
  • Permanent arteriolar degeneration
  • Nephritis

Gout

Saturnine gout (due to decreased excretion of uric acid)

Others

These include generalised weakness, anorexia, dyspepsia, emaciation, exhaustion, irritability, foul breath, headache, vertigo, alopecia, and dizziness.

questions.text: A 4-year-old boy is brought to the clinic for irritability, poor appetite, and stomach pain. The family recently moved into an old house that is under renovation. Examination reveals pallor and a blue line on the gums. Blood smear findings are noted. What is the most likely finding on the blood smear in this child with suspected lead poisoning?
questions.explanation:
Hematological Manifestation

Description

Mechanism

Microcytic-Hypochromic Anemia

Small, pale RBCs (microcytes)

Inhibition of heme synthesis occurs through the inactivation of enzymes such as ALA dehydratase, ALA synthetase, decarboxylase, and ferrochelatase, due to lead interference.

Basophilic Stippling

Blue granules in RBCs on smear

Accumulation of ribosomes due to RNA degradation inhibition (due to the inhibition of the enzyme pyrimidine 5-nucleotidase).

Anisocytosis

Variation in RBC sizes

Ineffective erythropoiesis

Poikilocytosis

Variation in RBC shapes

Disruption of normal maturation processes

Elevated Free Erythrocyte Protoporphyrin (FEP)

Increased protoporphyrin levels

Impaired conversion of protoporphyrin to heme

Increased Zinc Protoporphyrin (ZnP)

Elevated levels in blood

Accumulation due to disruption of normal heme production

Conditions associated with Basophilic stippling:

Conditions associated with Microcytic hypochromic anaemia:
  • Lead poisoning
  • Thalassemia (Beta- thalassemia)
  • Sideroblastic anemia
  • Arsenic poisoning
  • Alcoholism
  • Pyrimidine 5′-Nucleotidase deficiency
  • Megaloblastic anemia
  • Severe infections (e.g., malaria)
  • Myelodysplastic syndromes
  • Chronic inflammatory conditions
  • Iron deficiency anaemia
  • Lead poisoning
  • Thalassemia
  • Anaemia of chronic disease (inflammatory)
  • Sideroblastic anemia

questions.text: A 6 year old girl was brought to the clinic by her parents, who reported symptoms including irritability, stomach pain, difficulty concentrating, decreased appetite, and fatigue. The examination showed signs of anaemia and facial circumoral pallor, leading the doctor to suspect heavy metal poisoning. What is the most common route of exposure to this poison in children?

options.label: C
options.text: Ingestion of lead dust or paint chips

questions.correct_answer: C. Ingestion of lead dust or paint chips
questions.explanation:
Route

Example

Inhalational (Option A)
  • Plumbing factories (most common)
  • Pipe factories
  • Paint factories

Oral (ingestion)
  • Paint (most common route in children) (Option B)
  • Water (contaminated) (Option C)

Through skin (Option D)
  • Absorption through the scalp (sindoor)
  • In chemical factory workers.

Compounds

Uses

Lead acetate (sugar of lead)

Therapeutics: used as an astringent and topical sedative for sprains previously. (most common)

Lead Sulfide

Collyrium (Surma) (least common)

Lead tetroxide

Vermillion (sindoor)

Tetraethyl lead
  • Antiknock agent (mixed with petrol to prevent detonation in internal combustion engines)
  • Causes encephalopathy

Lead carbonate (white lead)

Paints

Lead oxide (litharge)

Glazing of pottery and enamelware

questions.text: A 32-year-old male presents to the emergency department after ingesting the seeds given in the image. He has severe abdominal pain, bloody vomiting, dizziness, and a rapid, weak pulse. What is the mechanism of action of the toxic compound present in the seeds?

options.label: A
options.text: Inhibits calcium ion channels, causing cell death.

options.label: B
options.text: Blocks RNA polymerase, preventing protein synthesis

options.label: C
options.text: Binds to ribosomal RNA, inhibiting protein synthesis.

options.label: D
options.text: Disrupts mitochondrial function, leading to energy failure.

questions.correct_answer: B. Blocks RNA polymerase, preventing protein synthesis

questions.text: A 45-year-old construction worker presented with severe health issues over several weeks, including abdominal pain, persistent nausea, throat pain, fatigue, and intermittent diarrhoea. During hospitalisation, he developed confusion, slurred speech, and distinctive skin changes (shown in the image below) indicative of heavy metal poisoning. Which of the following clinical features is commonly associated with this condition?
questions.explanation:
Acute Arsenic Poisoning

Chronic Arsenic Poisoning

Dermal

  • Hair loss
  • Mees lines (Aldrich-Mees line or Reynold’s line): Transverse bands of opacity in nails. (Option C)
  • Melanosis (neck, eyelids, nipples)
  • Bowen’s disease
  • Facial oedema
  • Hyperkeratosis
  • Black foot disease (Peripheral gangrene)

  • Hyperpigmentation (raindrop pattern)

  • Skin cancer (commonly squamous cell carcinoma).

Ocular

  • Conjunctivitis
  • Lacrimation
  • Dimension of Vision

Gastrointestinal

  • Abdominal pain
  • Metallic taste
  • Garlicky odour
  • Dysphagia
  • Vomiting
  • Diarrhoea (bloody or rice water)
  • Anorexia
  • Nausea
  • Vomiting
  • Diarrhea
  • Weight loss

Airway

  • Upper airway irritation
  • Nasal septum perforation
  • Laryngitis
  • Bronchitis

Liver

  • Fatty degeneration
  • Hepatomegaly
  • Jaundice
  • Cirrhosis

Kidney

  • Oliguria
  • Uraemia
  • Nephritic changes

Neurological

  • Hyperpyrexia
  • Convulsions
  • Coma
  • Encephalopathy
  • Polyneuritis (glove & stocking type)

 

  • Tremor
  • Ataxia
  • Limb tenderness
  • Difficulty in walking

Haematological

–
  • Anaemia
  • Leucopenia
  • Thrombocytopenia
  • Basophilic stippling (Rare in arsenic poisoning and common in lead poisoning)

  • Karyorrhexis
  • Pancytopenia

Cardiac

  • Tachycardia
  • Hypotension
  • Cardiac arrhythmias
  • Hypertension
  • Myocarditis

questions.text: A 40-year-old man was found dead in his home with no signs of forced entry. Family members reported he had been unwell for weeks, experiencing throat and abdominal pain, vomiting, and purging. Autopsy findings indicated emaciation, keratosis, and white streaks on his nails, suggesting heavy metal poisoning. Which of the following postmortem findings is not true in this case?

options.label: B
options.text: Red velvety mucosa in the stomach

questions.correct_answer: A. Rigor mortis sets in quickly
questions.explanation:
External findings

Internal findings

  • Emaciation
  • Raindrop pigmentation
  • Keratosis
  • Alopecia
  • White streaks on nails (Aldrich Mees’ lines)
  • Jaundice and muscle wasting,
  • Nasal septum ulceration.
  • Sunken eyeballs
  • Cyanosed and shrunken body.
  • Rigor mortis (sets in late and persists for a prolonged duration) (Option A)
  • Reddening of stomach mucosa (red velvet or strawberry) due to gastrointestinal congestion. (Option B)
  • Flea-bitten appearance of the stomach (due to focal haemorrhages). (Option D)
  • The inflammation and presence of “rice water” contents in the intestines.
  • Subendocardial haemorrhages in the heart. (Option C)
 
  • Fatty degeneration of the heart, liver, and kidneys.
  • Along with routine viscera and body fluids, the items preserved for chemical analysis are:
  • A piece of long bone (preferably femur)
  • A bunch of pulled scalp hair
  • A wedge of muscle
  • A small portion of skin (from the back of the trunk)

questions.text: A 28 year old man is brought to the emergency department in an altered mental state after reportedly using a speedball for a more intense high. His friends mention he often combines a powerful stimulant with another drug to enhance his experience. What is the composition of a speedball that he is likely using?
questions.explanation:
Composition

Heroin + Cocaine

Route

Injected, Smoked (Moon Rock)

Effects

Produce a double effect of the initial high “kick” of cocaine, followed by the subsequent euphoric “rush” of heroin.

Clinical features

The presence of needle marks along with the features of:

 
  • Cocaine: Tachypnea, tachycardia, restlessness, anxiety, loss of appetite, insomnia, hypertension, tremors, fever, mydriasis, and hallucinations.
 
  • Heroin: It is an opioid & causes reduced respiration, hypotension, bradycardia, delirium, hallucinations, slurred speech, sedation, coma, ataxia, muscle weakness, hypothermia, miosis, and needle marks.

Fatal dose

50 mg

Fatal period

12 hours

questions.text: A 30 year old male is brought to the emergency department after experiencing severe anxiety and chest pain following a night of partying. He reports using cocaine, and the medical team notes his elevated blood pressure and signs of agitation. Which of the following is the most likely complication of cocaine use?
questions.explanation:
Cocaine

Origin

Leaves of Erythroxylum coca

Local names

Coke, snow, Cadillac, White lady

Physical properties

Colourless, odourless, crystalline, bitter taste

Mechanism of action
  • It is a potent central nervous system (CNS) stimulant that produces initial euphoria and increased energy, followed by depression as its effects wear off.
  • It enhances alertness and activity while stimulating the autonomic nervous system, leading to increased heart rate and elevated blood pressure.

Route of administration

Snorting, Smoking, IV injection

Signs of abuse
  • Septal perforation
  • Crack hands (multiple blackened, hyperkeratotic lesions on the fingers and palms).
  • Black staining of tongue and teeth

Effects

Stages

  1. Stage of excitement
  • Feeling of well-being
  • Loss of depression and fatigue
  • Excited and restless
  • Tingling sensation in hands and feet
  • Increased heart rate
  • Increase in temperature
  • Rapid and deep respiration
 
  1. Stage of depression
  • Profuse perspiration
  • Convulsion
  • Reduced respiratory rate

Complications

  • Cardiac arrhythmia (Option B)
  • Cardiac failure
  • Cardiovascular collapse
  • Cerebrovascular accident
  • Aortic dissection
  • Myocardial infarction
  • Skin necrosis
  • Intracerebral hemorrhage
  • Formication (Cocaine Bugs)

Management of fatal dose
  • Maintain airway, breathing and circulation
  • If ingested: Gastric lavage with potassium permanganate
  • If snorted: Wash the nasal mucous membrane with water
  • If injected: Ligature over the injection site
  • Amyl nitrite via inhalation route
  • Thiamine 100 mg IV injection
  • Naloxone hydrochloride 2mg IV injection
  • Symptomatic management for convulsions using barbiturates

questions.text: Match the following drugs with their commonly known local names. Drugs Local names 1. Cocaine a. Smack 2. MDMA b. Weed 3. Heroin c. Molly 4. Cannabis d. White lady 5. LSD e. Acid
questions.explanation:
Drugs

Local names

Cocaine

Coke, snow, Cadillac, white lady, crack (cocaine + baking soda + water)

MDMA

Molly, love drug, ecstasy

Heroin

Smack, brown sugar, Black tar, speedball(mixed with cocaine)

Cannabis

Pot, grass, dope, weed, hash, Mary Jane, M.J

LSD

Acid, Alice, Angel in the Sky, Lucy

Ketamine

K, Special K, Kit-Kat, K Hole

Methamphetamine

Ice, Glass, Crystal meth, Meth, Speed

questions.text: A 24-year-old male with no history of violent behavior suddenly becomes agitated and aggressive after consuming a high dose of cannabis. He attacks several people without warning and later has no recollection of the incident. This condition, triggered by excessive cannabis use, is known as?
questions.explanation:
Effects of cannabis use

Acute

Chronic

Psychiatric symptoms

  • Euphoria (increased subjective experiences and disorientation)
  • Disturbed thought pattern
  • Altered concepts of time and space, lapse of attention
  • Impaired immediate memory function
  • Well-being and self-confidence
  • Rapid and impaired speech
  • Increased awareness of stimuli
  • Fear of dying

Physical symptoms

  • Increased appetite and thirst
  • Nausea and dizziness
  • Ataxia or tremors
  • Conjunctival injection
  • Somnolence

Hashish psychosis (Option B)

  • Auditory and visual hallucination
  • Delusion of persecution
 

Run amok begins with a period of depression, followed by violent outbursts aimed at harming others, and ends with either surrender or suicide.

 

Amotivational syndrome (Option A)

  • Loss of interest in day-to-day activity
  • Lethargy
  • Loss of age-appropriate behaviour
 

Other effects: Decreased testosterone levels leading to gynecomastia, low sperm count

questions.text: Which of the following options correctly orders the potency of cannabis products from most potent to least potent?
questions.correct_answer: C. Hashish oil > Charas > Ganja > Bhang
questions.explanation:
Form of cannabis

Percentage of active principle

Bhang

15%

Ganja

15-25%

Charas

25-40%

Hashish Oil

>50%

questions.text: A 30-year-old man presents to the emergency department with symptoms of anticholinergic toxicity after ingesting an herbal preparation containing Datura seeds. Upon examination, he shows signs of confusion and dilated pupils. Which of the following statements about the seed morphology of Datura and Capsicum is incorrect?

options.label: A
options.text: Datura seeds are large and thick, while capsicum seeds are small and thin

options.label: B
options.text: Datura seeds are kidney-shaped, while capsicum seeds are rounded

options.label: C
options.text: Datura seed has a smooth surface, while capsicum seeds have numerous depressions

options.label: D
options.text: Datura seeds are dark yellowish-brown, while capsicum seeds are pale yellow

questions.correct_answer: C. Datura seed has a smooth surface, while capsicum seeds have numerous depressions
questions.explanation:
Features

Datura seeds

Capsicum seeds

Size (Option A)

Large and thick

Small and thin

Shape (Option B)

Kidney shaped

Rounded

Color (Option C)

Dark or yellowish-brown

Pale - yellow

Surface

Numerous small depressions

Smooth

Margin

Laterally compressed and double edge at the convex border

Convex border is simple and sharp

Smell

Odourless

Pungent

Taste

Bitter

Pungent

Cut surface (longitudinal)

The embryo is curved outward at the hilum

The embryo is curved inward like the figure ‘6.’

Active principle

hyoscine (scopolamine), hyoscyamine and traces of atropine

Capsaicin and capsicin

Effects

Antimuscarinic effects on the CNS

It acts as an irritant poison, causing pain and irritation.

questions.text: A 24-year-old male presents to the emergency room after ingesting kidney-shaped seeds while camping. Upon examination, he exhibits dry mouth, dilated pupils, blurred vision, flushed skin, tachycardia, hallucinations, agitation, and disorientation. What is the most appropriate antidote for this poisoning?
questions.explanation:
Toxicity

Antidote

Mechanism of action

Datura/anticholinergics toxicity

Physostigmine (Option B)

Inhibits acetylcholinesterase enzyme

Opium

Naloxone (Option A)

Opioid receptor antagonist

Organophosphates

Atropine

Pralidoxime

Muscarinic antagonist

Cholinesterase reactivation

Acetaminophen

N-acetyl-cysteine

Replenishes Glutathione

Methanol

Fomepizole (Option D)

Inhibitor of alcohol dehydrogenase

Benzodiazepine

Flumazenil

Inhibits GABA receptors

Cyanide

Eli Lilly antidote Kit (3-step approach)
  1. Amyl nitrate: Oxidises haemoglobin to methemoglobin, which scavenges cyanide.
  1. Sodium nitrate: causes cyanide to detach from the heme group of cytochrome oxidase.
  • Amyl nitrate is used as a temporary measure until IV Sodium nitrate can be given.
  1. Sodium thiosulphate:It activates an enzyme that converts cyanide to a less toxic agent, thiocyanate.

questions.text: A 40-year-old woman presents with blistering and severe itching on her arms after applying the juice from a black seed, as shown in the image. She also experiences nausea and abdominal pain. Which of the following statements is not true?

options.label: A
options.text: Often used in malingering for artificial bruises.

options.label: C
options.text: Commonly used for Arrow and Cattle poisoning.

options.label: D
options.text: Large oral doses can be potentially fatal

questions.correct_answer: C. Commonly used for Arrow and Cattle poisoning.

questions.text: A 25-year-old female presents to the ER after ingesting seeds from a plant, as shown in the image. She reports severe abdominal pain, nausea, and bloody diarrhoea. Upon examination, she exhibits weakness, tachycardia, and dilated pupils. What is the primary active principle responsible for the toxic effects seen in this patient?
